conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
Initially, the light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are elongated and positioned away from the objects, indicating that the light source is above and possibly slightly to one side.
When the light source moves downward, it gets closer to the objects.
The angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes, becoming more perpendicular to the objects.
As the light source moves downward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects.
The direction of the shadows will change, becoming more directly underneath the objects rather than elongated away from them.
The size of the shadows will decrease as the light source moves downward.
This is because the light rays are more directly overhead, reducing the spread of the shadow.
The shadows will become more compact and less elongated.
Imagine the light source moving directly above each object. The shadows would be directly underneath the objects, and their size would be minimized.
As the light source continues to move downward, the shadows will continue to shrink and align more closely with the base of the objects.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and become smaller in size.
The elongation of the shadows will decrease, and they will appear more compact and directly beneath the objects.
